p: Moving beyond a notion of the hospital as a space within which ever-more protective barriers are erected to distance clinical care from everyday life, a logic exemplified by the image above, a spatialized ethnographic engagement draws attention to the divergent practices of care and protection that shape institutional spaces. As Alain Epelboin (e.g., Epelboin et al. 2005) has shown, situating the technical immediacies of VHF care, protection, and intervention in broader relational and social context can contribute to improving the management of VHF outbreaks. Placing such insights within fine-grained ethnographic accounts of the institutional histories and symbolic meanings of clinical spaces would further nuance our understanding of transmission dynamics.
